11.10.18  3:52 am   Hi Bill.

So I've got a pretty good relative pitch. Once I know the note of one pitch, I can pretty much tell the rest because I have a reference. But I want to tell a pitch without a reference.

Can you teach me how to do that?

     I know perfect pitch is not the most important thing in the world but I just want to know if it's possible to learn.

     I want to identify notes without reference.

11.9.18  4:15 pm   Hi bill. Do you think I should play more piano to learn how to improv better (follow the sound in my head with my hands) or study more music theory to improv better?

      Or maybe do the first one first and then gradually apply music theory to what I'm doing so I can analyze and understand what I'm doing, and thus do it better and more consistently in the future?

     Also, I'm considering getting an electric keyboard even though we have a really grand grand piano in our house because it would help me write/improv music without worrying about what my family members hearing it (I would use headphone plug-ins) because I've heard that professional musicians limit the part of their brain that worries about what other people think while they're improv-ing and until I'm brave enough to do that I think it would be nice to have a private environment to try this in. Thoughts?
11.9.18  2:50 pm   Is it unreasonable to think that by listening to your music and reading the ueqstions page I can get an idea of what kind of person you are?

11.9.18  4:39 am   How well does the legal system work?

     How often are cops, judges, etc, corrupt, prejudiced, etc?

     How often does a guilty person go free, or visa versa?

     How often do laws end up being enforced in ways that are clearly not how they're intended?

     How often does a victim not pursue action because they can't afford it?

     Is it even possible to answer these questions with any degree of certainty?
